<P>Bronze by gold, Miss Douce's head by Miss Kennedy's head, over the crossblind

of the Ormond bar heard the viceregal hoofs go by, ringing steel.



<P>-- Is that her? asked Miss Kennedy.



<P>Miss Douce said yes, sitting with his ex, pearl grey and <I>eau de Nil</I>.



<P>-- Exquisite contrast, Miss Kennedy said.



<P>When all agog Miss Douce said eagerly:



<P>-- Look at the fellow in the tall silk.



<P>-- Who? Where? gold asked more eagerly.



<P>-- In the second carriage, Miss Douce's wet lips said, laughing in the

sun. He's looking. Mind till I see.



<P>She darted, bronze, to the backmost corner, flattening her face against

the pane in a halo of hurried breath.



<P>Her wet lips tittered:



<P>-- He's killed looking back.



<P>She laughed:



<P>-- O wept! Aren't men frightful idiots?



<P>With sadness.



<P>Miss Kennedy sauntered sadly from bright light, twining a loose hair

behind an ear. Sauntering sadly, gold no more, she twisted twined a hair.

Sadly she twined in sauntering gold hair behind a curving ear.



<P>-- It's them has the fine times, sadly then she said.



<P>A man.



<P>Bloowho went by by Moulang's pipes, bearing in his breast the sweets

of sin, by Wine's antiques in memory bearing sweet sinful words, by Carroll's

dusky battered plate, for Raoul.



<P>The boots to them, them in the bar, them barmaids came. For them unheeding

him he banged on the counter his tray of chattering china. And



<P>-- There's your teas, he said.



<P>Miss Kennedy with manners transposed the teatray down to an upturned

lithia crate, safe from eyes, low.



<P>-- What is it? loud boots unmannerly asked.



<P>-- Find out, Miss Douce retorted, leaving her spyingpoint.



<P>-- Your <I>beau</I>, is it?



<P>A haughty bronze replied:



<P>-- I'll complain to Mrs de Massey on you if I hear any more of your

impertinent insolence.



<P>-- I mperthnthn thnthnthn, bootsnout sniffed rudely, as he retreated

as she threatened as he had come.



<P>Bloom.



<P>On her flower frowning Miss Douce said:



<P>-- Most aggravating that young brat is. If he doesn't conduct himself

I'll wring his ear for him a yard long.



<P>Ladylike in exquisite contrast.



<P>-- Take no notice, Miss Kennedy rejoined.



<P>She poured in a teacup tea, then back in the teapot tea. They cowered

under their reef of counter, waiting on footstools, crates upturned, waiting

for their teas to draw. They pawed their blouses, both of black satin,

two and nine a yard, waiting for their teas to draw, and two and seven.



<P>Yes, bronze from anear, by gold from afar, heard steel from anear, hoofs

ring from afar, and heard steelhoofs ringhoof ringsteel.



<P>-- Am I awfully sunburnt?



<P>Miss Bronze unbloused her neck.



<P>-- No, said Miss Kennedy. It gets brown after. Did you try the borax

<P>Miss Douce halfstood to see her skin askance in the barmirror gildedlettered

where hock and claret glasses shimmered and in their midst a shell.



<P>-- And leave it to my hands, she said.



<P>-- Try it with the glycerine, Miss Kennedy advised.



<P>Bidding her neck and hands adieu Miss Douce



<P>-- Those things only bring out a rash, replied, reseated. I asked that

old fogey in Boyd's for something for my skin.



<P>Miss Kennedy, pouring now fulldrawn tea, grimaced and prayed:



<P>-- O, don't remind me of him for mercy'sake!



<P>-- But wait till I tell you, Miss Douce entreated.



<P>Sweet tea Miss Kennedy having poured with milk plugged both two ears

with little fingers.



<P>-- No, don't, she cried.



<P>-- I won't listen, she cried.



<P>But Bloom?



<P>Miss Douce grunted in snuffy fogey's tone:



<P>-- For your what? says he.



<P>Miss Kennedy unplugged her ears to hear, to speak: but said, but prayed

again:



<P>-- Don't let me think of him or I'll expire. The hideous old wretch!

That night in the Antient Concert Rooms.



<P>She sipped distastefully her brew, hot tea, a sip, sipped sweet tea.



<P>-- Here he was, Miss Douce said, cocking her bronze head three quarters,

ruffling her nosewings. Hufa! Hufa!



<P>Shrill shriek of laughter sprang from Miss Kennedy's throat. Miss Douce

<P>-- O! shrieking, Miss Kennedy cried. Will you ever forget bis goggle

<P>Miss Douce chimed in in deep bronze laughter, shouting:



<P>-- And your other eye!



<P>Bloowhose dark eye read Aaron Figatner's name. Why do I always think

Figather? Gathering figs I think. And Prosper Lor&eacute;'s huguenot name.

By Bassi's blessed virgins Bloom's dark eyes went by. Bluerobed, white

<P>By went his eyes. The sweets of sin. Sweet are the sweets.



<P>Of sin.



<P>In a giggling peal young goldbronze voices blended, Douce with Kennedy

your other eye. They threw young heads back, bronze gigglegold, to let

piercing notes.



<P>Ah, panting, sighing. Sighing, ah, fordone their mirth died down.



<P>Miss Kennedy lipped her cup again, raised, drank a sip and giggle-giggled.

<P>-- O greasy eyes! Imagine being married to a man like that, she cried.

With his bit of beard!



<P>Douce gave full vent to a splendid yell, a full yell of full woman,

<P>-- Married to the greasy nose! she yelled.



<P>Shrill, with deep laughter, after bronze in gold, they urged each other

<P>Married to Bloom, to greaseaseabloom.



<P>-- O saints above! Miss Douce said, sighed above her jumping rose. I

<P>-- O, Miss Douce! Miss Kennedy protested. You horrid thing!



<P>And flushed yet more (you horrid!), more goldenly.



<P>By Cantwell's offices roved Greaseabloom, by Ceppi's virgins, bright

<P>Flushed less, still less, goldenly paled.



<P>Into their bar strolled Mr Dedalus. Chips, picking chips off one of

his rocky thumbnails. Chips. He strolled.



<P>-- O welcome back, Miss Douce.



<P>He held her hand. Enjoyed her holidays?.



<P>-- Tiptop.



<P>He hoped she had nice weather in Rostrevor.



<P>-- Gorgeous, she said. Look at the holy show I am. Lying out on the

<P>Bronze whiteness.



<P>-- That was exceedingly naughty of you, Mr Dedalus told her and pressed

her hand indulgently. Tempting poor simple males.



<P>Miss Douce of satin douced her arm away.



<P>-- O go away, she said. You're very simple, I don't think.



<P>He was.



<P>-- Well now, I am, he mused. I looked so simple in the cradle they christened

me simple Simon.



<P>-- You must have been a doaty, Miss Douce made answer. And what did

the doctor order today?



<P>-- Well now, he mused, whatever you say yourself. I think I'll trouble

you for some fresh water and a half glass of whisky.



<P>Jingle.



<P>-- With the greatest alacrity, Miss Douce agreed.



<P>With grace of alacrity towards the mirror gilt Cantrell and Cochrane's

<P>-- By Jove, he mused. I often wanted to see the Mourne mountains. Must

<P>Yes. He fingered shreds of hair, her maidenhair, her mermaid's, into

<P>None not said nothing. Yes.

gentleman, stylishly dressed in an indigoblue serge suit made by George

Robert Mesias, tailor and cutter, of number five Eden quay, and wearing

a straw hat very dressy, bought of John Plasto of number one Great Brunswick

street, hatter. Eh? This is the jingle that joggled and jingled. By Dlugacz'

porkshop bright tubes of Agendath trotted a gallantbuttocked mare.



<P>-- Answering an ad? keen Richie's eyes asked Bloom.



<P>-- Yes, Mr Bloom said. Town traveller. Nothing doing, I expect.



<P>Bloom mur: best references. But Henry wrote: it will excite me. You

know now. In haste. Henry. Greek ee. Better add postscript. What is he

playing now? Improvising intermezzo. P. S. The rum tum tum. How will you

pun? You punish me? Crooked skirt swinging, whack by. Tell me I want to.

Know. O. Course if I didn't I wouldn't ask. La la la ree. Trails off there

sad in minor. Why minor sad? Sign H. They like sad tail at end. P. P. S.

La la la ree. I feel so sad today. La ree. So lonely. Dee.



<P>He blotted quick on pad of Pat. Envel. Address. Just copy out of paper.

Murmured: Messrs Callan, Coleman and Co, limited. Henry wrote:

<BLOCKQUOTE>Miss Martha Clifford

<BR>c/o P. O.

<BR>Dolphin's barn lane

<BR>Dublin.</BLOCKQUOTE>

Blot over the other so he can't read. Right. Idea prize titbit. Something

detective read off blottingpad. Payment at the rate of guinea per col.

Matcham often thinks the laughing witch. Poor Mrs Purefoy. U. p.: up.



<P>Too poetical that about the sad. Music did that. Music hath charms Shakespeare

said. Quotations every day in the year. To be or not to be. Wisdom while

you wait.



<P>In Gerard's rosery of Fetter lane he walks, greyed-auburn. One life

is all. One body. Do. But do.



<P>Done anyhow. Postal order stamp. Postoffice lower down. Walk now. Enough.

Barney Kiernan's I promised to meet them. Dislike that job. House of mourning.

Walk. Pat! Doesn't hear. Deaf beetle he is.



<P>Car near there now. Talk. Talk. Pat! Doesn't. Settling those napkins.

Lot of ground he must cover in the day. Paint face behind on him then he'd

be two. Wish they'd sing more. Keep my mind off.



<P>Bald Pat who is bothered mitred the napkins. Pat is a waiter hard of

his hearing. Pat is a waiter who waits while you wait. Hee hee hee hee.

He waits while you wait. Hee hee. A waiter is he. Hee hee hee hee. He waits

while you wait. While you wait if you wait he will wait while you wait.

Hee hee hee hee. Hoh. Wait while you wait.



<P>Douce now. Douce Lydia. Bronze and rose.



<P>She had a gorgeous, simply gorgeous, time. And look at the lovely shell

she brought.



<P>To the end of the bar to him she bore lightly the spiked and winding

seahorn that he, George Lidwell, solicitor, might hear.



<P>-- Listen! she bade him.



<P>Under Tom Kernan's ginhot words the accompanist wove music slow. Authentic

fact. How Walter Bapty lost his voice. Well, sir, the husband took him

by the throat. <I>Scoundrel</I>, said he. You'll <I>sing no more lovesongs</I>.

He did, sir Tom. Bob Cowley wove. Tenors get wom. Cowley lay back.



<P>Ah, now he heard, she holding it to his ear. Hear! He heard. Wonderful.

She held it to her own and through the sifted light pale gold in contrast

glided. To hear.



<P>Tap.



<P>Bloom through the bardoor saw a shell held at their ears. He heard more

faintly that that they heard, each for herself alone, then each for other,

hearing the plash of waves, loudly, a silent roar.



<P>Bronze by a weary gold, anear, afar, they listened.



<P>Her ear too is a shell, the peeping lobe there. Been to the seaside.

Lovely seaside girls. Skin tanned raw. Should have put on coldcream first

make it brown. Buttered toast. O and that lotion mustn't forget. Fever

near her mouth. Your head it simply. Hair braided over: shell with seaweed.

Why do they hide their ears with seaweed hair? And Turks their mouth, why?

Her eyes over the sheet, a yashmak. Find the way in. A cave. No admittance

except on business.



<P>The sea they think they hear. Singing. A roar. The blood is it. Souse

in the ear sometimes. Well, it's a sea. Corpuscle islands.



<P>Wonderful really. So distinct. Again. George Lidwell held its murmur,

hearing: then laid it by, gently.



<P>-- What are the wild waves saying? he asked her, smiled.



<P>Charming, seasmiling and unanswering Lydia on Lidwell smiled.



<P>Tap.



<P>By Larry O'Rourke's, by Larry, bold Larry O', Boylan swayed and Boylan

turned.



<P>From the forsaken shell Miss Mina glided to her tankard waiting. No,

she was not so lonely archly Miss Douce's head let Mr Lidwell know. Walks

in the moonlight by the sea. No, not alone. With whom? She nobly answered:

with a gentleman friend.



<P>Bob Cowley's twinkling fingers in the treble played again. The landlord

has the prior. A little time. Long John. Big Ben Lightly he played a light

bright tinkling measure for tripping ladies, arch and smiling, and for

their gallants, gentlemen friends. One: one, one, one: two, one, three,

four.



<P>Sea, wind, leaves, thunder, waters, cows lowing, the cattle market,

cocks, hens don't crow, snakes hissss. There's music everywhere. Ruttledge's

door: ee creaking. No, that's noise. Minuet of <I>Don Giovanni</I> he's

playing now. Court dresses of all descriptions in castle chambers dancing.

Misery. Peasants outside. Green starving faces eating dockleaves. Nice

that is. Look: look, look, look, look, look: you look at us.



<P>That's joyful I can feel. Never have written it. Why? My joy is other

joy. But both are joys. Yes, joy it must be. Mere fact of music shows you

are. Often thought she was in the dumps till she began to lilt. Then know.



<P>M'Coy valise. My wife and your wife. Squealing eat. Like tearing silk.

When she talks like the clapper of a bellows. They can't manage men's intervals.

Gap in their voices too. Fill me. I'm warm, dark, open. Molly in <I>qui

est homo</I>: Mercadante. My ear against the wall to hear. Want a woman

who can deliver the goods.



<P>Jog jig jogged stopped. Dandy tan shoe of dandy Boy Ian socks skyblue

clocks came light to earth.



<P>O, look we are so! Chamber music. Could make a kind of pun on that.

It is a kind of music I often thought when she. Acoustics that is. Tinkling.

Empty vessels make most noise. Because the acoustics, the resonance changes

according as the weight of the water is equal to the law of falling water.

Like those rhapsodies of Liszt's, Hungarian, gipsyeyed. Pearls. Drops.

Rain. Diddle iddle addle addle oodle oodle. Hiss. Now. Maybe now. Before.



<P>One rapped on a door, one tapped with a knock, did he knock Paul de

Kock, with a loud proud knocker, with a cock carracarracarra cock. Cockcock.



<P>Tap.



<P>-- <I>Qui sdegno</I>, Ben, said Father Cowley.



<P>-- No, Ben, Tom Kernan interfered, <I>The Croppy Boy</I>. Our native

Doric.



<P>-- Ay do, Ben, Mr Dedalus said. Good men and true.



<P>-- Do, do, they begged in one.



<P>I'll go. Here, Pat, return. Come. He came, he came, he did not stay.

To me. How much?



<P>-- What key? Six sharps?



<P>-- F sharp major, Ben Dollard said.



<P>Bob Cowley's outstretched talons gripped the black deep sounding chords.



<P>Must go prince Bloom told Richie prince. No, Richie said. Yes, must.

Got money somewhere. He's on for a razzle backache spree. Much? He seehears

lipspeech. One and nine. Penny for yourself. Here. Give him twopence tip.

Deaf, bothered. But perhaps he has wife and family waiting, waiting Patty

come home. Hee hee hee hee. Deaf wait while they wait.



<P>But wait. But hear. Chords dark. Lugugugubrious. Low. In a cave of the

dark middle earth. Embedded ore. Lumpmusic.



<P>The voice of dark age, of unlove, earth's fatigue made grave approach,

and painful, come from afar, from hoary mountains, called on good men and

true. The priest he sought, with him would he speak a word.



<P>Tap.



<P>Ben Dollard's voice barreltone. Doing his level best to say it. Croak

of vast manless moonless womoonless marsh. Other comedown. Big ships' chandler's

business he did once. Remember: rosiny ropes, ships' lanterns. Failed to

the tune of ten thousand pounds. Now in the Iveagh home. Cubicle number

so and so. Number one Bass did that for him.



<P>The priest's at home. A false priest's servant bade him welcome. Step

in. The holy father. Curlycues of chords.



<P>Ruin them. Wreck their lives. Then build them cubicles to end their

days in. Hushaby. Lullaby. Die, dog. Little dog, die.



<P>The voice of warning, solemn warning, told them the youth had entered

a lonely hall, told them how solemn fell his footstep there, told them

the gloomy chamber, the vested priest sitting to shrive.



<P>Decent soul. Bit addled now. Thinks he'll win in <I>Answers</I> poets'

picture puzzle. We hand you crisp five pound note. Bird sitting hatching

in a nest. Lay of the last minstrel he thought it was. See blank tee what

domestic animal? Tee dash ar most courageous mariner. Good voice he has

still. No eunuch yet with all his belongings.



<P>Listen. Bloom listened. Richie Goulding listened. And by the door deaf

Pat, bald Pat, tipped Pat, listened.



<P>The chords harped slower.



<P>The voice of penance and of grief came slow, embellished, tremulous.

Ben's contrite beard confessed: <I>in nomine Domini</I>, in God's name.

He knelt. He beat his hand upon his breast, confessing: <I>mea culpa</I>.



<P>Latin again. That holds them like birdlime. Priest with the communion

corpus for those women. Chap in the mortuary, coffin or coffey, <I>corpusnomine</I>.

Wonder where that rat is by now. Scrape.



<P>Tap.



<P>They listened: tankards and Miss Kennedy, George Lidwell eyelid well

expressive, fullbusted satin, Kernan, Si.



<P>The sighing voice of sorrow sang. His sins. Since easter he had cursed

three 'times. You bitch's bast. And once at masstime he had gone to play.

Once by the churchyard he had passed and for his mother's rest he had not

prayed. A boy. A croppy boy.



<P>Bronze, listening by the beerpull, gazed far away. Soulfully. Doesn't

half know I'm. Molly great dab at seeing anyone looking.



<P>Bronze gazed far sideways. Mirror there. Is that best side of her face?

They always know. Knock at the door. Last tip to titivate.



<P>Cockcarracarra.



<P>What do they think when they hear music? Way to catch rattlesnakes.

Night Michael Gunn gave us the box. Tuning up. Shah of Persia liked that

best. Remind him of home sweet home. Wiped his nose in curtain too. Custom

his country perhaps. That's music too. Not as bad as it sounds. Tootling.

Brasses braying asses through uptrunks. Doublebasses, helpless, gashes

in their sides. Woodwinds mooing cows. Semigrand open crocodile music hath

jaws. Woodwind like Goodwin's name.



<P>She looked fine. Her crocus dress she wore, lowcut, belongings on show.

Clove her breath was always in theatre when she bent to ask a question.

Told her what Spinoza says in that book of poor papa's. Hypnotised, listening.

Eyes like that. She bent. Chap in dresscircle, staring down into her with

his operaglass for all he was worth. Beauty of music you must hear twice.

Nature woman half a look. God made the country man the tune. Met him pike

hoses. Philosophy. O rocks!



<P>All gone. All fallen. At the siege of Ross his father, at Gorey all

his brothers fell. To Wexford, we are the boys of Wexford, he would. Last

of his name and race.



<P>I too, last my race. Milly young student. Well, my fault perhaps. No

son. Rudy. Too late now. Or if not? If not? If still?



<P>He bore no hate.



<P>Hate. Love. Those are names. Rudy. Soon I am old.



<P>Big Ben his voice unfolded. Great voice, Richie Goulding said, a flush

struggling in his pale, to Bloom, soon old but when was young.



<P>Ireland comes now. My country above the King. She listens. Who fears

to speak of nineteen four? Time to be shoving. Looked enough.



<P>-- <I>Bless me, father</I>, Dollard the croppy cried. <I>Bless me and

let me go</I>.



<P>Tap.



<P>Bloom looked, unblessed to go. Got up to kill: on eighteen bob a week.

Fellows shell out the dibs. Want to keep your weathereye open. Those girls,

those lovely. By the sad sea waves. Chorusgirl's romance. Letters read

out for breach of promise. From Chickabiddy's own Mumpsypum. Laughter in

court. Henry. I never signed it. The lovely name you.



<P>Low sank the music, air and words. Then hastened. The false priest rustling

soldier from his cassock. A yeoman captain. They know it all by heart.

The thrill they itch for. Yeoman cap.



<P>Tap. Tap.



<P>Thrilled, she listened, bending in sympathy to hear.



<P>Blank face. Virgin should say: or fingered only. Write something on

it: page. If not what becomes of them? Decline, despair. Keeps them young.

Even admire themselves. See. Play on her. Lip blow. Body of white woman,

a flute alive. Blow gentle. Loud. Three holes all women. Goddess I didn't

see. They want it: not too much polite. That's why he gets them. Gold in

your pocket, brass in your face. With look to look: songs without words.

Molly that hurdygurdy boy. She knew he meant the monkey was sick. Or because

so like the Spanish. Understand animals too that way. Solomon did. Gift

of nature.



<P>Ventriloquise. My lips closed. Think in my stom. What?



<P>Will? You? I. Want. You. To.



<P>With hoarse rude fury the yeoman cursed. Swelling in apoplectic bitch's

bastard. A good thought, boy, to come. One hour's your time to live, your

last.



<P>Tap. Tap.



<P>Thrill now. Pity they feel. To wipe away a tear for martyrs. For all

things dying, want to, dying to, die. For that all things born. Poor Mrs

Purefoy. Hope she's over. Because their wombs.



<P>A liquid of womb of woman eyeball gazed under a fence of lashes, calmly,

At each slow satiny heaving bosom's wave (her heaving embon) red rose rose

slowly, sank red rose. Heartbeats her breath: breath that is life. And

all the tiny tiny fernfoils trembled of maidenhair.



<P>But look. The bright stars fade. O rose! Castille. The morn. Ha. Lidwell.

For him then not for. Infatuated. I like that? See her from here though.

Popped corks, splashes of beerfroth, stacks of empties.



<P>On the smooth jutting beerpull laid Lydia hand lightly, plumply, leave

it to my hands. All lost in pity for croppy. Fro, to: to, fro: over the

slowly down, a cool firm white enamel baton protruding through their sliding

ring.



<P>With a cock with a carra.



<P>Tap. Tap. Tap.



<P>I hold this house. Amen. He gnashed in fury. Traitors swing.



<P>The chords consented. Very sad thing. But had to be.



<P>Get out before the end. Thanks, that was heavenly. Where's my hat. Pass

by her. Can leave that <I>Freeman</I>. Letter I have. Suppose she were

Tisntdall Farrell, Waaaaaaalk.



<P>Well, I must be. Are you off? Yrfmstbyes. Blmstup. O'er ryehigh blue.

<P>By deaf Pat in the doorway, straining ear, Bloom passed.



<P>At Geneva barrack that young man died. At Passage was his body laid.

Dolor! O, he dolores! The voice of the mournful chanter called to dolorous

<P>By rose, by satiny bosom, by the fondling hand, by slops, by empties,

<P>Tap. Tap. Tap.



<P>Pray for him, prayed the bass of Dollard. You who hear in peace. Breathe

<P>Scaring eavesdropping boots croppy bootsboy Bloom in the Ormond hallway

<P>-- Come on, Ben, Simon Dedalus said. By God, you're as good as ever

<P>-- Better, said Tomgin Kernan. Most trenchant rendition of that ballad,

upon my soul and honour it is.

<P>Ben Dollard bulkily cachuchad towards the bar, mightily praisefed and

<P>Big Benaden Dollard. Big Benben. Big Benben.



<P>Rrr.



<P>And deepmoved all, Simon trumping compassion from foghorn nose, all

<P>-- Ben machree, said Mr Dedalus, clapping Ben's fat back shoulderblade.

Fit as a fiddle, only he has a lot of adipose tissue concealed about his

<P>Rrrrrrsss.



<P>-- Fat of death, Simon, Ben Dollard growled.



<P>Richie rift in the lute alone sat: Goulding, Collis, Ward. Uncertainly

<P>Miss Mina Kennedy brought near her lips to ear of tankardone.



<P>-- Mr Dollard, they murmured low.



<P>-- Dollard, murmured tankard.



<P>Tank one believed: Miss Kenn when she: that doll he was: she doll: the

tank.



<P>He murmured that he knew the name. The name was familiar to him, that

is to say. That was to say he had heard the name of Dollard, was it? Dollard,

yes.



<P>Yes, her lips said more loudly, Mr Dollard. He sang that song lovely,

murmured Mina. And <I>The last rose of summer</I> was a lovely song. Mina

loved that song. Tankard loved the song that Mina.



<P>'Tis the last rose of summer Dollard left Bloom felt wind wound round

inside.



<P>Gassy thing that cider: binding too. Wait. Postoffice near Reuben J's

one and eightpence too. Get shut of it. Dodge round by Greek street. Wish

I hadn't promised to meet. Freer in air. Music. Gets on your nerves. Beerpull.

Her hand that rocks the cradle rules the. Ben Howth. That rules the world.



<P>Far. Far. Far. Far.



<P>Tap. Tap. Tap. Tap.



<P>Up the quay went Lionelleopold, naughty Henry with letter for Mady,

with sweets of sin with frillies for Raoul with met him pike hoses went

<P>Tap blind walked tapping by the tap the curbstone tapping, tap by tap.



<P>Cowley, he stunts himself with it; kind of drunkenness. Better give

ears. Not lose a demisemiquaver. Eyes shut. Head nodding in time. Dotty.

You daren't budge. Thinking strictly prohibited. Always talking shop. Fiddlefaddle

about notes.



<P>All a kind of attempt to talk. Unpleasant when it stops because you

never know exac. Organ in Gardiner street. Old Glynn fifty quid a year.

Queer up there in the cockloft alone with stops and locks and keys. Seated

wadding or something in his no don't she cried), then all of a soft sudden

<P>Pwee! A wee little wind piped eeee. In Bloom's little wee.

<P>-- By the by there's a tuningfork in there on the...

<P>Blind he was she told George Lidwell second I saw. And played so exquisitely,

<P>-- Shout! Ben Dollard shouted, pouring. Sing out!



<P>-- 'lldo! cried Father Cowley.



<P>Rrrrrr.



<P>I feel I want...



<P>Tap. Tap. Tap. Tap. Tap.



<P>-- Very, Mr Dedalus said, staring hard at a headless sardine.



<P>Under the sandwichbell lay on a bier of bread one last, one lonely,

<P>-- Very, he stared. The lower register, for choice.

<P>Bloom went by Barry's. Wish I could. Wait. That wonderworker if I had.

Twentyfour solicitors in that one house. Litigation. Love one another.

Piles of parchment. Messrs Pick and Pocket have power of attorney. Goulding,

<P>But for example the chap that wallops the big drum. His vocation: Micky

Pom. Pompedy. Jolly for the wife. Asses' skins. Welt them through life,

then wallop after death. Pom. Wallop. Seems to be what you call yashmak

or I mean kismet. Fate.



<P>Tap. Tap. A stripling, blind, with a tapping cane, came taptaptapping

<P>Instruments. A blade of grass, shell of her hands, then blow. Even comb

Pom. It is music, I mean of course it's all pom pom pom very much what

march along. Pom.



<P>I must really. Fff. Now if I did that at a banquet. Just a question

of custom shah of Persia. Breathe a prayer, drop a tear. All the same he

up. Wonder who was that chap at the grave in the brown mackin. O, the whore

of the lane!



<P>A frowsy whore with black straw sailor hat askew came glazily in the

day along the quay towards Mr Bloom. When first he saw that form endearing.

Yes, it is. I feel so lonely. Wet night in the lane. Horn. Who had the?

Heehaw. Shesaw. Off her beat here. What is she? Hope she. Psst! Any chance

of your wash. Knew Molly. Had me decked. Stout lady does be with you in

the brown costume. Put you off your stroke. That appointment we made. Knowing

we'd never, well hardly ever. Too dear too near to home sweet home. Sees

me, does she? Looks a fright in the day. Face like dip. Damn her! O, well,

she has to live like the rest. Look in here.



<P>In Lionel Marks's antique saleshop window haughty Henry Lionel Leopold

oozing maggoty blowbags. Bargain: six bob. Might learn to play. Cheap.

Let her pass. Course everything is dear if you don't want it. That's what

good salesman is. Make you buy what he wants to sell. Chap sold me the

Swedish razor he shaved me with. Wanted to charge me for the edge he gave

it. She's passing now. Six bob.



<P>Must be the cider or perhaps the burgund.



<P>Near bronze from anear near gold from afar they chinked their clinking

<P>Bloom viewed a gallant pictured hero in Lionel Marks's window. Robert

<P>They lifted.

takes her place among</I>.
